results.headline: Tracking Ballet’s Pull on Youth Worldwide

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of First Position

results.summary_short: Children from around the world come to New York for an intense ballet competition in the documentary “First Position.”

results.headline: Superheroes, Super Battles, Super Egos

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Avengers

results.summary_short: Joss Whedon’s long-awaited superhero opus “The Avengers” arrives with a big cast, frequent battles and abundant banter among its characters.

results.headline: A Malevolent Matriarch and Her Evil Brood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mother's Day

results.summary_short: In “Mother’s Day,” Rebecca De Mornay is back as a more tight-lipped version of the psychotic nanny she embodied in “The Hand That Rocks the Cradle.”

results.headline: When There Really Is Not a Drop to Drink

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Call at the Oasis

results.summary_short: Jessica Yu’s “Last Call at the Oasis” delivers frightening predictions of water shortages in reasonable tones.

results.headline: Oh, for a Rug to Sweep Secrets Under

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Perfect Family

results.summary_short: In “The Perfect Family,” Kathleen Turner plays a homemaker up for her parish’s Catholic Woman of the Year award while contending with her gay daughter and adulterous son.

results.headline: A Prodigy’s Manifesto (Not on the Mount)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jesus Henry Christ

results.summary_short: In the whimsical comedy “Jesus Henry Christ,” a child prodigy seeks out his biological father and denies the existence of God.

results.headline: Midlife Crisis Solved by Reconnecting With Craft

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chronicling A Crisis

results.summary_short: “Chronicling a Crisis” is a deeply honest and scattered documentary.

results.headline: Dancing on Her Own Grave With a Spring in Her Step

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Little Bit of Heaven

results.summary_short: A carefree advertising whiz won’t let cancer get in the way of romance, or her sense of humor, in “A Little Bit of Heaven.”

results.headline: Swashbumblers Roiling Madcap Seas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pirates! Band of Misfits

results.summary_short: This stop-motion animation film from Aardman Animations about a band of hapless high-seas troublemakers is a curiosity cabinet of visual pleasures.

results.headline: A Small-Town Murder by Just the Nicest Guy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bernie

results.summary_short: Shirley MacLaine and Jack Black form an unlikely bond in “Bernie,” Richard Linklater’s dark comedy.

results.headline: 3 Settings, 3 Countries and the World of Women Who Live by Their Bodies

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Whores' Glory

results.summary_short: Michael Glawogger’s documentary “Whores’ Glory” compares the world’s oldest profession, as practiced in three settings, in three countries: Bangladesh, Thailand and Mexico.

results.headline: Machismo, Obtained via Machete
results.display_title: Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale

results.summary_short: “Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale” tells the real-life tale of a 1930 battle between Taiwanese warriors and Japanese invaders.

results.headline: A Murderer Tapping at His Chamber Door

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Raven

results.summary_short: “The Raven” reimagines Poe in his final days as a heroic crime fighter, tracking down a diabolical serial killer.

results.headline: Underachievers Stumble Into Romantic Bliss

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Giant Mechanical Man

results.summary_short: A lost soul unfit for even temporary work meets a street-corner mime and finds love in the romantic comedy “The Giant Mechanical Man.”

results.headline: Lovebirds in a Predictable Pickle: Silly but So What?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Five-Year Engagement

results.summary_short: In “The Five-Year Engagement,” Jason Segel and Emily Blunt play a couple trying to reconcile professional ambition with the demands and rewards of a fulfilling relationship.

results.headline: The Guru in the Basement Promises a Journey to ... Something

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sound of My Voice

results.summary_short: A young couple go undercover to investigate an enigmatic woman leading what may be a cult in “Sound of My Voice.”

results.headline: Martial Arts Fighter Tackles the Russian Mob

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Safe

results.summary_short: In “Safe,” Jason Statham plays a mixed-martial-arts fighter whose wife is murdered by the Russian mafia after he won’t throw a fight.

results.headline: Making a New Life in a Seamy New York

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Restless City

results.summary_short: “Restless City” follows the travails of a West African immigrant and aspiring singer who sells pirated CDs on the New York streets.

results.headline: Images of a Ballet Company Moving Through History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Joffrey: Mavericks of American Dance

results.summary_short: “Joffrey” documents not only that classical ballet company’s history but also dance history, explained by interviews with former company members and rare footage of ballet rehearsals.

results.headline: Intoxicated by Language, a Poet Is Destroyed by Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Broken Tower

results.summary_short: James Franco plays the poet Hart Crane in “The Broken Tower.”
